snippet: Interviews with a 22-year-old man who opened fire on Americans reveal the rage that officials worry may disrupt the training mission at the core of the United States’ withdrawal plan.
abstract: Interviews with Mahmood, Afghan soldier who opened fire on Americans before escaping into arms of the Taliban, reveal rage that many Afghans feel against the United States; officials worry that country's growing resentment may disrupt training mission at core of American withdrawal plan.

byline.contributor: Sangar Rahimi and Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting from Kabul, and an employee of The New York Times from Asadabad.

lead_paragraph: Interviews with a 22-year-old man who opened fire on Americans reveal the rage that officials worry may disrupt the training mission at the core of the United States’ withdrawal plan.

headline.seo: Afghan Soldier’s Journey From Friend to Killer of Americans
headline.main: An Afghan Soldier’s Journey From Ally to Enemy of America
headline.print_headline: Afghan Soldier’s Journey to Killer of Americans

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
